column4: I have a problem trying to save my firewall rules to a file: when I do "iptables-save > /etc/iptables.up.rules" I get the error "bash: /etc/iptables.up.rules: Permission denied"
this file is writable by root only
I did that through sudo
I did "sudo iptables-save > /etc/iptables.up.rules"
how about redirecting the output to another file and than coping it over to /etc/...?
you mean to write that to another directory?
sudo iptables-save > tmpfile; sudo cp tmpfile /etc/...
same result: permission denied
is this the first user you created?
yes, brand new :)
only the first user is allowed to issue sudo
what permissions does this file have? the /etc/... one?
drwxr-xr-x 109 root root
this is a directory, not a file. you cannot cat to a directory
yes, /etc/ is a directory, so?
you are trying to put the output of a command into a file. but you got permission denied. my question is what permissions does have the file you are trying to output to
the file does not exist yet
you cannot create a file in a directory to which you have write access? this is very, very unlikely
I agree, that's really weird, it never happened before
I can't write to /etc/ nor to /opt/
despite the fact I am using sudo
maybe the filesystem is mounted read only? check if your /etc/fstab have an option like "remount-readonly" for the / file system
it does exist. just it's not enabled by default. check in /etc/passwd
